awd_titl_txt: Analyzing Weather Data from Historic Logbooks to Assess Changing Wind and Atmospheric Pressure Patterns
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project analyzes historic weather patterns using American whaling ship logbooks to understand how oceanic wind and pressure patterns have varied spatially over the past approximately 250 years. The project integrates disparate scholarly subfields as historians work with oceanographers to extend the instrumental meteorological record back two centuries and with a broader geographical distribution than is currently available. For safety, mariners recorded hazards to navigation on their charts, as well as weather data. The project extracts substantial meteorological data from historic logbooks, records heretofore inaccessible to modern scientists, and makes them freely available online. The investigators use these historic weather records to address current questions regarding shifts in wind and atmospheric pressure patterns. These include changes in high pressure systems that are related to the subtropical dry zones on land and the westerly storm tracks that steer the passage of rain-bearing weather systems. The understanding of past variability in these wind and atmospheric pressure patterns has societal relevance as these patterns directly impact agricultural productivity and can improve weather forecasting and modelling. Furthermore, the research can identify weather and navigational data that are of practical benefit to contemporary shipping, underscoring the project's importance to modern commercial navigation and maritime defense. The project includes training students in convergent science. Research results will be made available to the public via informal learning opportunities at museums and to the broader scientific community at interdisciplinary conferences.

Long-term datasets are invaluable to meteorological research as they establish a baseline against which to measure recent changes, can validate models, and illuminate how the atmosphere and ocean interact. The historic logbooks being analyzed contain systematic weather observations (e.g., wind strength and direction, storms, sea state, precipitation, air temperature, atmospheric pressure) that will significantly extend the instrumental record. The newly-recovered historical data are combined with existing observational and reanalysis products to understand robustness and long-term context of variations in the Earth's atmospheric circulation over the past approximately 250 years. The investigators specifically consider: (a) changes in the Hadley circulation that are related to the expansion of subtropical dry zones, such as in the U.S. Southwest; and (b) changes in strength and position of subtropical high-pressure systems as manifestations of the descending limb of Hadley Cell circulation and changes in strength and position of the Southern Hemisphere westerly winds that were traversed by the whalers on their way to historical whaling grounds and which have recently experienced strong poleward shifts. Understanding long-term variability in subtropical high-pressure systems and westerly storm tracks has relevance for any regions affected by such meteorological patterns.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project assessed historical weather patterns using American whaling ship logbooks to understand how oceanic wind patterns have varied over the past ~250 years. For this, the project surveyed, mined, and analyzed the 18th- to 19th-century whaling voyage logbooks held in the Nantucket Historical Association and the New Bedford Whaling Museum collections. For safety, mariners needed to systematically record maritime weather data, in particular winds. The project generated a custom-built database for recording meteorological data extracted from whaling ship logbooks and to date contains ~74,000 (sub)daily weather entries spanning the period 1792-1913 CE. These historical weather records can then be used to address current climate questions related to shifts in wind and pressure patterns over the global oceans, as was demonstrated in initial proof-of-concepts.

Following extensive data quality control of the entries, the descriptive, qualitative information of winds recorded in the daily entries of the whaling ship logbooks need to be transferred to quantitative wind strength. This can be realized given the systematic terminology used by the whalers. A key was developed and further refined that categorizes each unique wind descriptor used in the ~70,000 daily wind entries according to a Beaufort wind force reading. The resultant quantitative information is compared against monthly and daily winds from reanalysis products.

A comparison of the wind force distribution of the whaling ship logbook data compared to daily 20th Century Reanalysis displays that both datasets are almost equally distributed, which suggests an accurate conversion to the Beaufort wind force scale and underlines the value and accuracy of the whaling ship logbook data. The analyses demonstrate that the wind data from the whaling ship logbooks agrees with mean wind patterns and past climate variability for the North Atlantic over the last two hundred years and therefore provides valuable insights into the past wind patterns in this area complementing existing reanalysis products. The project overall successfully demonstrated proof-of-concept how qualitative descriptive wind information can be turned into quantitative information that can be directly compared with numerical data from reanalyses.

The project integrated disparate scholarly subfields: historians and oceanographers working together to push the instrumental climate record back, with broader geographical distribution than currently available. As such, the project also provided an opportunity to educate the next generation of interdisciplinary researchers by training students with hands-on experience in research. Over the duration of the grant, a total of six (under)graduates in STEM fields, including students from under-represented minorities, have gained valuable hands-on experiences in interdisciplinary research at WHOI using historical ship logbook data generated as part of this grant, and four (under)graduate students in the humanities received training in archival research.

Research is made available to the general public through multiple talks at museums and libraries across New England, to (under)graduate student audiences through lectures, and to the broader scientific community at interdisciplinary conferences nationally and internationally. So far, the project led to a series of (inter)national conference presentations (eight conference oral or poster presentations), most of which with student involvement, as well as five scientific lectures to colleagues and students, and eight outreach talks to the public and educators. The project also provided opportunities for art-science collaborations with multiple pieces of artwork showcased at art exhibits in Massachusetts and Rhode Island to showcase the project to a broader audience. Furthermore, results from this project received extensive national and international media coverage in print and online, as well as via radio and TV.
